content:
Economic, social, environmental and <span class="word-wrap-span">governancespan> reforms are <span class="word-wrap-span">essentialspan>, says <span class="word-wrap-span">Christinespan> Lagarde of the IMF

In the musical “Hamilton”, the main character and a founding father of America, Alexander Hamilton, ponders a crucial question just before he lifts his <span class="word-wrap-span">pistolspan> in a <span class="word-wrap-span">duelspan>: “What is a <span class="word-wrap-span">legacyspan>?” We need to ask ourselves the same question, as we look at the great challenges of the 21st century.

For many, one answer is the United Nations’ <span class="word-wrap-span">Sustainablespan> Development Goals (SDGs). Set out in 2015 with the hopes of being achieved by 2030, they <span class="word-wrap-span">embodyspan> the <span class="word-wrap-span">contourspan>s of the world we want and indeed need: free of <span class="word-wrap-span">povertyspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">deprivationspan>; a <span class="word-wrap-span">fairerspan> world; a world that respects natural limits.

They are the <span class="word-wrap-span">antidotespan> to the loss of trust in institutions of all kinds, and the loss of faith in global co-operation. The SDGs <span class="word-wrap-span">overlapspan> with the <span class="word-wrap-span">mandatespan> of the International Monetary Fund to the extent that they affect sustainable and <span class="word-wrap-span">inclusivespan> economic growth. This is the case in four main areas: economic, social, environmental and <span class="word-wrap-span">governancespan>.

Consider the economic challenges of low-income countries. Over 1bn people have been lifted out of extreme <span class="word-wrap-span">povertyspan> since 1990, amid global <span class="word-wrap-span">integrationspan>. This is a <span class="word-wrap-span">remarkablespan> achievement, unprecedented across the entire span of human history. Yet almost 800m people remain <span class="word-wrap-span">mirespan>d in extreme <span class="word-wrap-span">povertyspan> today.

With health too, child <span class="word-wrap-span">mortalityspan> has fallen by half since 1990, thanks in no small part to the <span class="word-wrap-span">Millenniumspan> Development Goals, the <span class="word-wrap-span">precursorspan> of the SDGs. But more than 5m children still die each year before their fifth birthday, and in nearly all cases <span class="word-wrap-span">basspan>ic medical <span class="word-wrap-span">interventionspan>s could save their lives.

The same is true with education. There has been great progress, but great gaps remain. In sub-Saharan Africa about a fifth of children do not attend primary school; the figure is a third for lower secondary school, and more than half for upper secondary school. And too many of those in school are not learning. Across the world, 58% of students in primary and lower secondary school—617m children—do not have <span class="word-wrap-span">basspan>ic <span class="word-wrap-span">proficiencyspan> in reading and <span class="word-wrap-span">mathematicsspan>. 

Given what we know about the future of work, how can anybody thrive in the modern economy without at least a secondary education? As H.G. Wells put it, “Human history becomes more and more a race between education and <span class="word-wrap-span">catastrophespan>.” According to <span class="word-wrap-span">UNESCOspan>, world <span class="word-wrap-span">povertyspan> would be cut in half if all people completed secondary education. And one could make similar points about the importance of the other <span class="word-wrap-span">basspan>ic economic needs, such as health care, clean water and <span class="word-wrap-span">sanitationspan>, clean energy, and even the <span class="word-wrap-span">availabilityspan> of finance.

There are <span class="word-wrap-span">complicationspan>s, however. The need to <span class="word-wrap-span">rampspan> up spending comes at a time when debt in low-income countries is looking increasingly <span class="word-wrap-span">precariousspan>. Some 40% of them now face high risk of debt <span class="word-wrap-span">distressspan> or are unable to service their debt fully, up from just 21% five years ago. On top of that, low-income countries are borrowing more on non-<span class="word-wrap-span">concessionalspan> terms, increasing interest service costs. If <span class="word-wrap-span">implementspan>ing the SDGs is a race, it is increasingly an uphill one.

<span class="word-wrap-span">Ultimatelyspan>, supporting the SDGs in low-income countries must be a global <span class="word-wrap-span">priorityspan>. It is not only the right thing to do; it is the smart thing to do. It is not only about <span class="word-wrap-span">solidarityspan>; it is about self-interest. For without sustainable development at home, the bubbling economic and social pressures—made worse by rapid population growth and growing environmental stress—will surely spill across borders, including through mass movements of peoples.

Now, consider the second broad <span class="word-wrap-span">dimensionspan> of the SDGs: <span class="word-wrap-span">inclusionspan>—both in terms of income <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> and gender equity.

Income <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> has become one of the global economy’s greatest challenges. For sure, some regions have seen <span class="word-wrap-span">remarkablespan> progress in reducing <span class="word-wrap-span">povertyspan> and expanding the middle class over the past few decades. And <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> has been reduced between countries. But not within countries.

Since 1980 the top 1% globally has seen twice as much of the gains from growth as the bottom 50%. Over that period, income <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> has been on the rise in most advanced economies. This is partly due to technology, partly due to global <span class="word-wrap-span">integrationspan>, and partly due to policies that favour capital over labour.

The <span class="word-wrap-span">implicationspan>s are alarming, especially among these advanced economies. In these countries, rising <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> is contributing to the withering-away of entire communities and ways of life. It is leading to the unravelling of social <span class="word-wrap-span">cohesionspan> and sense of a common destiny. And it is fuelling the growing tendency to replace <span class="word-wrap-span">deliberationspan> with demonisation; partnership with <span class="word-wrap-span">parochialismspan>.

A key issue here is that <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> can undermine the idea of a <span class="word-wrap-span">meritocraticspan> society, as a small minority gain <span class="word-wrap-span">privilegespan>d access to the many tangible and <span class="word-wrap-span">intangiblespan> benefits needed to get ahead, whether it is education, cultural <span class="word-wrap-span">enrichmentspan> or well-placed connections. Such <span class="word-wrap-span">exclusionspan>, whereby <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> of outcomes feeds through to <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> of opportunities, hurts <span class="word-wrap-span">productivityspan> because it <span class="word-wrap-span">deprivespan>s the economy of the skills and talents of those who are excluded.

What about that other <span class="word-wrap-span">dimensionspan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">inclusionspan>, gender equity? The sad reality is that girls and women all over the world continue to face the daily indignities of <span class="word-wrap-span">discriminationspan>, <span class="word-wrap-span">harassmentspan>, and too often violence as well.

Just focusing on the economic <span class="word-wrap-span">dimensionspan> of gender equity, the situation is <span class="word-wrap-span">soberspan>ing. About 90% of countries have some legal restriction on women’s economic activity. In sub-Saharan Africa, IMF researchers <span class="word-wrap-span">estimatespan> that lowering gender <span class="word-wrap-span">inequalityspan> by ten percentage points could boost growth by two percentage points over five years.

And men need not lose out. By bringing more women into the fold, the economy can benefit from their talents, skills, unique <span class="word-wrap-span">perspectivespan>s and ideas. This <span class="word-wrap-span">diversityspan> should boost <span class="word-wrap-span">productivityspan> and lead to higher wages for all.

How do we increase this <span class="word-wrap-span">participationspan>? In low-income countries, it means reducing gender gaps in health and education, supporting financial <span class="word-wrap-span">inclusionspan>, investing in <span class="word-wrap-span">infrastructurespan> and ensuring better access to clean water and <span class="word-wrap-span">sanitationspan>. In advanced economies, policies such as <span class="word-wrap-span">parentalspan> leave and access to <span class="word-wrap-span">affordablespan> and high-quality <span class="word-wrap-span">childcarespan> can help a lot.

There is also the need to boost female leadership in the corporate world. Adding one more woman in <span class="word-wrap-span">seniorspan> management or to a corporate board raises the return on assets by eight to 13 <span class="word-wrap-span">basspan>is points (<span class="word-wrap-span">hundredthspan>s of a percentage point), according to one study. The IMF has just released research—“Women in Finance: A Case for Closing Gaps”, by Ratna Sahay and Martin Cihak ( here )—showing that in the financial sector, a higher share of women on bank boards is <span class="word-wrap-span">associatespan>d with greater financial <span class="word-wrap-span">resiliencespan>. At the same time, more women on banking supervision boards is <span class="word-wrap-span">associatespan>d with greater financial stability.

Yet there is a long way to go. Across the world, less than a fifth of bank board members and only 2% of bank chief <span class="word-wrap-span">executivespan>s are women. Finance would benefit enormously from greater <span class="word-wrap-span">diversityspan>. More diverse views in leadership means less likelihood of sinking into the quag<span class="word-wrap-span">mirespan> of groupthink and unconscious <span class="word-wrap-span">biasesspan>. More diverse views in leadership means more <span class="word-wrap-span">prudentspan> decision-making and a greater focus on longer-term sustainability.

The third SDG <span class="word-wrap-span">dimensionspan> is environmental: making sure that economic progress respects the natural limits of the planet. With each passing year, as <span class="word-wrap-span">heatwavespan>s become <span class="word-wrap-span">habitualspan> and storms become more frequent and <span class="word-wrap-span">ferociousspan>, climate change casts a shadow over our well-being and especially the well-being of our children. The <span class="word-wrap-span">moralspan> is clear: if we turn on nature, nature will turn on us.

Yet there are signs of hope. A few months after the SDGs were signed, the nations of the world joined the Paris Agreement to reduce carbon <span class="word-wrap-span">emissionspan>s with the goal of stopping global temperatures rising by more than two degrees <span class="word-wrap-span">Celsiusspan> over pre-industrial levels. This was a <span class="word-wrap-span">momentousspan> achievement, a <span class="word-wrap-span">remarkablespan> testament to the enduring power of multilateralism.

In turn, this commitment will <span class="word-wrap-span">entailspan> moving towards a zero-carbon global economy over the coming decades. This will not be easy, but I am <span class="word-wrap-span">convincespan>d that the world will be able to take the actions necessary to secure our collective future.

To <span class="word-wrap-span">nudgespan> this energy transition along, the IMF believes the best way is to put a price on carbon. This has many advantages. It is easy to <span class="word-wrap-span">administerspan> if done by <span class="word-wrap-span">integraspan>ting carbon charges into fuel-tax systems. It provides the right <span class="word-wrap-span">incentivespan>s for all <span class="word-wrap-span">dimensionspan>s of decarbonisation: better energy <span class="word-wrap-span">efficiencyspan>, shifting away from <span class="word-wrap-span">fossilspan> fuels in <span class="word-wrap-span">electricityspan> generation, and moving towards <span class="word-wrap-span">electrificationspan> in vehicles, buildings and industrial processes. It can reduce dangerous levels of air pollution. Plus, carbon taxes can raise revenue of about 1% to 2% of GDP a year.

Yet we have a long way to go. Even after China’s <span class="word-wrap-span">emissionspan>s-trading system comes into force in 2020, some 80% of global <span class="word-wrap-span">emissionspan>s will remain unpriced, according to the World Bank.

The fourth SDG <span class="word-wrap-span">pillarspan> is good <span class="word-wrap-span">governancespan>. In a real sense, <span class="word-wrap-span">governancespan> is the <span class="word-wrap-span">foundationspan> upon which everything else is built. Take <span class="word-wrap-span">corruptionspan>, a true economic and social <span class="word-wrap-span">plaguespan>. By undermining trust and delegitimising institutions, <span class="word-wrap-span">corruptionspan> makes it hard for countries to take the collective decisions needed to advance the common good.

Think about it. If some do not pay their fair share of taxes, governments cannot raise the revenue needed for SDG priorities.

Even worse, the <span class="word-wrap-span">legitimacyspan> of the whole system is undermined. If <span class="word-wrap-span">corruptionspan> is <span class="word-wrap-span">rampspan>ant, governments might be tempted to spend money on projects that generate <span class="word-wrap-span">kickbackspan>s but little social value—again, undermining the SDG agenda.

This is just the public sector. We also need the private sector to invest in long-term, sustainable projects that support the SDGs. But they are unlikely to do so if forced to pay a “<span class="word-wrap-span">corruptionspan> tax”. The <span class="word-wrap-span">genuinespan> risks and uncertainty that come with any investment decision will surely be magnified by <span class="word-wrap-span">corruptionspan>.

The private sector is not always the <span class="word-wrap-span">innocentspan> victim, of course. <span class="word-wrap-span">Corporationspan>s and investors are often too willing to offer <span class="word-wrap-span">bribespan>s. Major financial sectors are often too willing to welcome any kind of money.

What is the solution? Criminal <span class="word-wrap-span">enforcementspan> is <span class="word-wrap-span">essentialspan>, but on its own is not enough. IMF evidence shows that successful anti-<span class="word-wrap-span">corruptionspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">initiativespan>s are built on <span class="word-wrap-span">institutionalspan> reforms that emphasise transparency and <span class="word-wrap-span">accountabilityspan>, such as in all aspects of government budgets. For this reason, the IMF is increasing its focus on strong economic institutions. And when we find <span class="word-wrap-span">corruptionspan> to be <span class="word-wrap-span">macroeconomicspan> in <span class="word-wrap-span">magnitudespan>, we will not shy away from saying so.

These four areas—economic, social, environmental and <span class="word-wrap-span">governancespan>—point to how the IMF’s efforts support the SDGs. Though we work on them today, realising them is for the future: for our children and their children’s children. 

In “Hamilton”, after the <span class="word-wrap-span">protagonistspan> poses the question about one’s <span class="word-wrap-span">legacyspan>, he answers before losing his fateful <span class="word-wrap-span">duelspan>: “It’s planting seeds in a garden you never get to see.”

____________

<span class="word-wrap-span">Christinespan> Lagarde is the managing director of the International Monetary Fund. The article is adapted from the <span class="word-wrap-span">inauguralspan> Helen Alexander <span class="word-wrap-span">Memorialspan> Lecture that she presented on September 17th 2018 in London (full text here ). The lecture series is in honour of Dame Helen Alexander, a pioneering figure in British business and the chief <span class="word-wrap-span">executivespan> of The Economist Group from 1997 to 2008.
